awd_titl_txt: NRI: Small: Dynamic Locomotion: From Humans to Robots via Optimal Control
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop algorithms that can make robots and simulated characters move like humans. A range of dynamic locomotion tasks including walking, running, getting up and climbing, as well as task variations such as walking backwards, and concurrent tasks such as holding a cup of water while walking, will be studied. The approach is based on optimal control theory. Human movements will be analyzed, and the performance criteria with respect to which they are optimal will be identified. Algorithms that optimize the same performance criteria will then be developed.

Intellectual merit: Movement analysis will be based on a new mathematical framework where inference of performance criteria from observed movements becomes a convex optimization problem. Control synthesis will exploit new algorithms for real-time optimization which are able to plan long movement sequences involving multiple contact events. These algorithms rely on novel formulations of the physics of contact which are more amenable to numerical optimization, as well as a new physics simulator which exploits advances in parallel processing.

Broader impact: This research will change how robots and simulated characters move. Currently many robotic control systems with the appearance of dynamic movements are controlled in open loop, or are designed to execute one specific task. This work will enable robots to express more natural and versatile movements, as well as make robot programming more automated. The resulting controllers will also serve as models for human motor control.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we developed new optimal control methods that can synthesize life-like movements for simulated humanoid characters as well as humanoid robots.  Unlike most prior work which has relied on motion capture, reduced-order models, state machines or other hand-crafted representations, our methods work directly with the full dynamics of the system and generate movements automatically. This requires specification of a suitable cost function expressing the goals of the movement, such as get to a spatial target while minimizing energy. Our approach is based on trajectory optimization, where the entire sequence of poses is optimized jointly. A major difficulty in this line of work is the presence of multiple contacts, which make the dynamics non-smooth and result in optimization landscapes that are difficult for an optimization method to navigate. To overcome this difficulty, we developed domain-specific optimization methods as well as novel models of the physics of contact which result in smoother optimization landscapes. The resulting methods were able to generate a wide range of complex motions in simulation. Some of them were executed successfully on a physical platform - the Darwin humanoid robot. This was done by using ensemble optimization, where the same movement is optimized with respect to an ensemble of robot models and thereby becomes robust to variations in model parameters. This mitigated the effects of modeling errors, allowing execution of simulation-based trajectory on a complex robotic system without manual adjustment.
